word.entryDescription: a large building with many apartments
word.entryExample: I've heard that he lives on the top floor of a twenty-storey apartment block and never uses the lift!

word.entryDescription: to say sorry
word.entryExample: I must apologise to you all. It was my fault.
This appears to be a flat on the coast.

word.entryDescription: a feeling of wanting to eat
word.entryExample: Drinking water reduces our appetite, so we're less likely to snack through the day.

word.entryDescription: the sound of people showing that they like or approve of something by repeatedly hitting their open hands together
word.entryExample: 'Didn't she do well? Let's give her a big round of applause,' said my teacher.

word.entryDescription: a hard round fruit with a thin red or green skin and white flesh
word.entryExample: Apples are my favourite fruit.

word.entryDescription: a device, particularly an electrical one such as a fridge, washing machine, etc, that is used for a particular purpose in the home
word.entryExample: I can't believe we're talking about buying kitchen appliances again.

word.entryDescription: to request something, usually in writing, such as a job, a university place, a grant, etc
word.entryExample: You need a CV when you're applying for a job or going for an interview.

word.entryDescription: a formal arrangement to meet at a certain time
word.entryExample: Hello, I'd like a doctor's appointment, please.

word.entryDescription: a young person who is being trained in a working environment
word.entryExample: She started working as an apprentice.

word.entryDescription: the language of the Arabs
word.entryExample: There are going to be language taster sessions in Mandarin, Arabic and Russian.

word.entryDescription: a covered area with shops on both sides, or a passage with a roof supported by arches and columns
word.entryExample: They've rebuilt one of the market's arcades.

word.entryDescription: a person studying ancient societies by recovering and examining the remaining material evedence, e.g. graves, buildings, tools and pottery
word.entryExample: How long have the team of archaeologists been excavating the Agora?

word.entryDescription: somebody whose job is to design buildings
word.entryExample: I always wanted to be an architect when I was little.

word.entryDescription: the subject or practice of designing buildings, or the style of buildings
word.entryExample: We admired the amazing architecture of Barcelona.

word.entryDescription: to speak in disagreement with someone, usually with anger or force
word.entryExample: Thomas's parents did not argue about money.

word.entryDescription: an often angry discussion between people who disagree
word.entryExample: I remember lying in bed listening to an argument between them.

word.entryDescription: a statement or fact for or against a point
word.entryExample: You should present the arguments for and against in the middle paragraphs.

word.entryDescription: describes land, climate, soil, etc that is very dry and therefore does not support much life
word.entryExample: Sand devils happen in arid environments with no water.

word.entryDescription: the long part of your body between your shoulder and your hand
word.entryExample: First point to your arm, then point to your leg.

word.entryDescription: a comfortable chair with sides for your arms
word.entryExample: My grandma likes to sit in this armchair and watch TV.

word.entryDescription: the branch of the military that is trained mainly to fight on land
word.entryExample: Athens' money paid jurors and chancellors, built a navy and maintained the army.
Where can you go ice-skating around here?

word.entryDescription: something the police do when they take someone to the police station because they think that person has committed a crime
word.entryExample: It was very late last night when detectives arrested the suspect.

word.entryDescription: the act of arriving somewhere
word.entryExample: We'd like to announce the arrival of flight 201 from Barcelona.

word.entryDescription: to get to a place, especially at the end of a journey
word.entryExample: We think the plane will arrive at around 5:00 p.m.

word.entryDescription: the crime of deliberately causing damage by starting a fire
word.entryExample: When he was taken to court, the suspect was formally charged with arson.

word.entryDescription: a person who causes damage by setting fire to property
word.entryExample: When detectives caught the arsonist, he was still watching the burning building.

word.entryDescription: the study of painting, drawing, etc
word.entryExample: I like art because I love painting.

word.entryDescription: a place where works of art are displayed
word.entryExample: The Tate Modern is a big art gallery in London.

word.entryDescription: a written work on a particular subject in a newspaper or magazine
word.entryExample: The author of the article presents a very positive picture of the artist.

word.entryDescription: made or caused by people; not natural
word.entryExample: Eating patterns for lunch and dinner changed when artificial light was invented.

word.entryDescription: somebody who makes or performs art
word.entryExample: We know Picasso was a great artist.

word.entryDescription: immediately after
word.entryExample: The sky was blue, but as soon as the tornado arrived, it turned dark grey.

word.entryDescription: a large continent east of Europe between the Arctic, Pacific and Indian Oceans
word.entryExample: Elephants live on the grasslands of Asia and Africa.

word.entryDescription: to try to get (something) by requesting
word.entryExample: My dad asked him for directions and that's how we got home.

word.entryDescription: the meeting of a group of people for a particular purpose (legislative, religious, educational, or social)
word.entryExample: People in Athens weren't paid for their work in the council or in the assembly.

word.entryDescription: somebody who helps someone else do a job
word.entryExample: The magician's assistant lies in a box.

word.entryDescription: a medical condition in which the air passages in the lungs become narrow making breathing difficult
word.entryExample: If you suffer from asthma or allergies like hay fever, it's harder to get fit.

word.entryDescription: somebody who goes into space
word.entryExample: When I was young, I wanted to be an astronaut.

word.entryDescription: in your house/flat
word.entryExample: Is Lucy at home?
At last, we drove onto the ferry.

word.entryDescription: in school
word.entryExample: I learn English at school.

word.entryDescription: in front/behind
word.entryExample: The man who is sitting at the front of the houseboat looks very calm.

word.entryDescription: a person who competes in different sport disciplines, especially running, jumping, and throwing
word.entryExample: I jumped higher than all the other athletes.

word.entryDescription: a special mood or character of a place
word.entryExample: The atmosphere was great, but I didn't like the food very much.

word.entryDescription: the air around the Earth
word.entryExample: Burning fossil fuels is one of the causes of the increased concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.

word.entryDescription: related to the atmosphere
word.entryExample: Weather and climate also relate to atmospheric pressure and particles.

word.entryDescription: an island made of coral and in the shape of a ring
word.entryExample: The flora and fauna of this atoll must be preserved.

word.entryDescription: to include a computer file with an email
word.entryExample: I attach to this email a photograph of me and my brother Derek.
